content.raw:
Thank you for the contribution!

We follow a [code style](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development#Style) in Gazebo which, among other things, specifies 2-space indentation. Could you fix that please?

Also, please run the static code checker (`sh tools/code_check.sh` from gazebo's root directory), currently it is giving these errors:

~~~
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:85:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:86:  Missing space after ,  [whitespace/comma] [3]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:87:  Missing space after ,  [whitespace/comma] [3]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:88:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:89:  Missing space before ( in if(  [whitespace/parens] [5]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:91:  Missing spaces around =  [whitespace/operators] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:91:  Missing spaces around <  [whitespace/operators] [3]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:91:  Missing space before ( in for(  [whitespace/parens] [5]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:93:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:96:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:97:  Missing space before ( in if(  [whitespace/parens] [5]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:99:  Missing spaces around =  [whitespace/operators] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:99:  Missing spaces around <  [whitespace/operators] [3]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:99:  Missing space before ( in for(  [whitespace/parens] [5]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:103:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:104:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
gazebo/physics/JointController.cc:104:  Blank line at the end of a code block.  Is this needed?  [whitespace/blank_line] [3]

~~~

We follow a code style in Gazebo which, among other things, specifies 2-space indentation. Could you fix that please?

Also, please run the static code checker (sh tools/code_check.sh from gazebo's root directory), currently it is giving these errors:

content.raw: We're trying to reduce our use of boost. Would `std::to_string` work here?
content.html: We're trying to reduce our use of boost. Would std::to_string work here?

The automatically triggered Jenkins jobs seem not to be working for forks (I have the feeling they used to work...?)

content.raw:
`posPids` seems to be a map that uses the scoped names of the joint as a key ( #!/osrf/gazebo/src/67e62f2e7614f524fd8d36306d73390a14f9aa72/gazebo/physics/JointController.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#JointController.cc-71 ), while it seems that you try to use the string representation of a number as a key. 

Perhaps an alternative solution is using an iterator to interate on the map?
content.html:
posPids seems to be a map that uses the scoped names of the joint as a key ( #!/osrf/gazebo/src/67e62f2e7614f524fd8d36306d73390a14f9aa72/gazebo/physics/JointController.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#JointController.cc-71 ), while it seems that you try to use the string representation of a number as a key.

Perhaps an alternative solution is using an iterator to interate on the map?

content.raw:
Dear all,

I think that now it works. Thank you very much for your help!
content.html:
Dear all,

I think that now it works. Thank you very much for your help!

content.raw:
Just out of curiosity: why don't you directly use `iter->second` ? 

Searching the map with `iter->first` the for will have a asymptotic time complexity of O(n log(n)), while using `iter->second` you have a complexity of O(n), where n is the size of posPids .
content.html:
Just out of curiosity: why don't you directly use iter->second ?

Searching the map with iter->first the for will have a asymptotic time complexity of O(n log(n)), while using iter->second you have a complexity of O(n), where n is the size of posPids .

content.raw:
Dear Silvio,

Thank you for your suggestion. I will change it.
content.html:
Dear Silvio,

Thank you for your suggestion. I will change it.

content.raw: Actually if I used ```iter->second``` , then I should use ```iter->second.Reset()``` in the for loop , but I would prefer to mantain  ```this->dataPtr->posPids``` in the for loop.
content.html: Actually if I used iter->second , then I should use iter->second.Reset() in the for loop , but I would prefer to mantain this->dataPtr->posPids in the for loop.

what's the reason for keeping this->dataPtr->posPids in the for loop? iter->second has a nice performance advantage over another lookup with the operator[] .

In keeping with gazebo style guide, this would become:

  for (auto &iter : this->dataPtr->posPids)
  {
    iter.second.Reset();
  }

  for (auto &iter : this->dataPtr->velPids)
  {
    iter.second.Reset();
  }

content.raw: I have modified this file.Thank you for your suggestion
content.html: I have modified this file.Thank you for your suggestion

content.raw:
There's conflicts, but I've fixed them with a merge from default. I think if you pull to your fork and push, then it will resolve the conflicts:

~~~
hg pull #!/osrf/gazebo
hg push https://bitbucket.org/engine90/gazebo
~~~
content.html:
There's conflicts, but I've fixed them with a merge from default. I think if you pull to your fork and push, then it will resolve the conflicts:

hg pull #!/osrf/gazebo
hg push https://bitbucket.org/engine90/gazebo

content.html: @engine90, can you please merge this pull request which resolves the conflicts in this pull request?
